Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: A System for Representative Sampling of Powder Blends in Pharmaceutical Manufacturing
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will be realized first in pharmaceutical manufacturing where powder blends are needed to make tablets. These tablets constitute 40% of the most profitable pharmaceutical products, and nearly 80% of commercial products. The proposed device (sampler) will protect employees in pharmaceutical plants from exposure to potentially toxic drugs. The sampler will also be suitable for industrial powder blends such as vitamins, nutraceuticals, powdered milk, and other food products. The sampler will improve quality control in these companies and lead to representative sampling, thereby reducing risk to customers and patients. Sampling errors, which are frequent with the current approaches, will be reduced, increasing industrial productivity and avoiding production delays. The new sampler will have a positive financial impact in a number of powder processing industries and at the same time improve product quality.

The proposed project will provide funding to design devices to sample powder mixtures. The first work will be with the powder blends that become the tablets that many patients require. These new samplers are needed because the current practice in the pharmaceutical industry consists in inserting a spear into 10 - 12 pre-selected locations, which will not detect over or sub-potent blends outside of these locations. In contrast the new sampler will obtain a cross-section of a flowing powder, and all parts of the blend have the same possibility of being selected as a sample. The new device will be based on concepts first established within the mining industry, which have not been adapted to the pharmaceutical and powder industries. Experimental and computational methods will be used to design the new sampler, which will make it possible to implement statistical methods to assure representative sampling. The research team will work to provide a commercial sampler and support services to avoid delays in the introduction of new products and help pharmaceutical companies grow to obtain new revenues in less time.

POR.DRECONTENT:
SBIR Phase I: “A system for representative sampling for powder blends in pharmaceutical manufacturing” Project Outcomes Report

The research needed for the SBIR Phase I: “A system for representative sampling of powder blends in pharmaceutical manufacturing” has been completed. IBS Caribe, a small technology company, and the University of Puerto Rico at Mayaguez designed and constructed a proof-of-concept powder stream sampler during the award period.

The stream sampler is used with powder mixtures as they flow out of a blender towards a tablet or capsule filling machine.  These pharmaceutical products constitute approximately 80% of pharmaceutical sales. Pharmaceutical regulations require that these powder mixtures be analyzed to avoid the production of tablets or capsules with excess or lack of the labeled drug content. The currently used method requires the insertion of a metal spear (thief sampling)  into a blender to grab the powder mixture from a limited number of specified locations. The sample thief may alter the composition of the blend when it is inserted and has delayed the development of pharmaceutical products and the approval of new products needed by patients.

The innovative stream sampler works with the powder mixture that flows out of the blender. The sampler completely eliminates the insertion of a sample thief into the blender. The sampler also gives the user the opportunity to obtain a cross-section of the flowing powder stream without interrupting the manufacturing process. All parts of the pharmaceutical product obtained have the same opportunity of being selected by the stream sampler, as opposed to a limited number of pre-selected locations (thief sampler). Thus, the main objective is to make this new sampler the preferred method of pharmaceutical scientists and contribute to improving the quality of pharmaceutical products.

The flowing powder blend may be sampled in two different ways by the stream sampler. The first way is by collecting the powder mixture which can then be taken to an analytical instrument for analysis. The second way is to sample the flowing powder blend by analyzing the powder using non-destructive near infrared (NIR) spectroscopy. A NIR spectrometer may analyze a powder mixture just before it enters the sampler, or while it is within the sampler to determine the drug concentration in less than 5 seconds. Figure 1 shows the results for powder samples obtained in the first way using Ultraviolet (UV) spectroscopy and the second way using the non-destructive NIR spectroscopy technique. The proof-of-concept sampler was evaluated using powder mixtures where the caffeine concentration was varied from 10.50 to 19.50 %w/w. The caffeine powder is very cohesive (sticks together) and its physical properties are very similar to those of many currently approved drugs. The sampler showed excellent results in its initial testing. Table 1 shows a comparison between the results obtained using NIR spectroscopy versus UV spectroscopy. The results show significant agreement between both techniques, although NIR spectroscopy gave results closer to the caffeine concentration than those obtained using UV spectroscopy. These results are extremely positive in the development of this sampling device.

The project also included the development of variographic analysis as a new statistical method to evaluate drug uniformity in pharmaceutical blends.  Variographic analysis is possible with the stream sampler, but it is not possible with the current method of sampling (thief sampling). Variographic analysis makes it possible to estimate the sampling and analytical errors that may occur during the analysis of powder blends. This new software and the stream sampler will make it possible to improve pharmaceutical blending and sampling and reduce variations in the drug content of pharmaceutical products. The products from this award will contribute to the quality control of pharmaceutical products.
